page.title: 02Kirkconnel:In my young days
page.content: In 1928 the majority of boys leaving school worked in the local pits.Others went to farms,learned trades or got jobs in shops as message boys or trained as grocers with the Co-op. In the streets were water pumps in the shape of lions' heads with the water coming from their mouths.The petrol station used to be the{toll-house}and it cost an old half-penny to use the road which was then known as the Great Road. During the war German bombs fell on the railway line and the Co-op but apart from these and of course the men who fell in battle, Kirkconnel escaped the worst. The men used to meet in the Queensberry Arms or in the Reading Room to talk about current events, sport or politics. Contributer:R.Mathieson (Cushie Knowe)
